subject: Absurdly OT, but that's OK (Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...)
msgSnippet: ... Well, it s wrong: anything that happens in five minutes happens twice as quickly as if it happened in ten minutes. :) Saying that 5 minutes is slow is
messageBody:
Timothy Wall wrote:

>
> > On Wednesday, October 1, 2003, at 7:56:17 PM, Matt wrote:
> >
> >> To be technical here, Temperature is not a ratio variable, it is an
> >> interval variable. There is no 'zero' in temperature so it is not
> >> correct to say it is going to be twice as cold tomorrow. And yes, I
> >> know there is 'absolute' zero but ask any statistician and he will
> >> tell you that using ratios with our normal temperature scales is
> >> simply wrong. Using ratios with time works if you are using timed
> >> tests and define 'zero' as no time. Then yes, 5 minutes is twice as
> >> slow as 10 minutes.
>
> 5 minutes is twice as *slow* as 10 minutes? While that might be
> technically accurate from a narrow mathematical definition of "twice as
> slow", I doubt most readers of English would interpret it that way.

Well, it's wrong: anything that happens in five minutes happens twice as
quickly as if it happened in ten minutes. :)

Saying that "5 minutes is slow" is the problem. Minutes are not slow, or
fast. :)

Hey... we can *all* be pedantic.

> In general when making comparisons, I take "faster" to mean less time
> and "slower" to mean more time.

Not just you. :)
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services

Let's write software that people understand
